column3: Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities
column8: Animal production is dependent on the ecosystem contributions' to livestock provisioning. Raising of cattle and buffaloes also requires grazed biomass for many functions, such as plant and animal-based materials for feed and bedding.
column9: Raising of cattle and buffaloes depends on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to treat large quantities of manure, other solid wastes, and wastewater, mitigating their harmful effects.
column10: Raising of cattle and buffaloes is dependent on soil and sediment retention for maintenance of soils, preventing fertiliser run-off, and preventing or limiting exposed topsoil from being blown away by wind or washed away by rain. It also depends on landslide mitigation as the mass movement of soil and rock could damage the pastures, buildings and other infrastructure.
column11: Livestock agriculture is dependent on water purification by ecosystems to maintain or improve the quality of the water accessible to the animals as well as to break down or remove any pollutants emitted in the agricultural process.
column12: Raising of cattle and buffaloes is dependent on healthy and fertile soils to provide plant nutrition and health for the production of pastural crops and feedstocks.
column13: Raising of cattle and buffaloes is dependent on atmospheric and ecosystem-based dilution to disperse and reduce the impact of pollution on the animals, and also to disperse and reduce the impact of pollutants from the production on the ecosystems.
column14: Cattle farming is dependent on biological control, to control pests which irritate or impact the health of livestock. Pastural and feedstock crops fed to cattle are also dependent on any disease control naturally afforded.
column15: Raising of cattle and buffaloes depends on air filtration by ecosystems to reduce the impact of, and disperse air pollutants.
column16: Cattle and buffalo farming is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect animals, buildings and infrastructure from flooding.
column17: Raising of cattle and buffaloes depends on the provision of genetic material to enable selective breeding which is central to almost all livestock farming.
column18: Raising of cattle and buffaloes depends on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions necessary for cultivation of grassland or rangeland for animal feed, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage infrastructure.
column19: Raising of cattle and buffaloes depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for animals to drink, for washing animals and for cleaning yards and parlours.
column20: Maintenance of natural gene pool is important to maintain desirable genetic traits and variation in cattle.
column21: Livestock farmers might recruit shelterbelts and other cover crops/vegetation to act as a visual screen or a barrier to noise and dust arising as a result of cattle or dairy farming.
column22: Livestock farmers might recruit shelterbelts and other cover crops/vegetation to act as a visual screen or a barrier to dust arising as a result of cattle or dairy farming.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of animal production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for raising animals (e.g. forests and bodies of water can reduce local temperature, reducing heat stress for animals).
column25: Livestock production is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect animals, buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms. For example, the use of vegetation for livestock shelter is common in upland farming, whereby the provision of shelter provides a lifeline for cattle during storms.
column26: Livestock production depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient flow of water even during drier seasons (e.g. for animals to drink, cleaning and sanitation) and to mitigate peak flows that could flood the pastures, builsings or associated infrastructure.
column27: Cattle farming is dependent on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to enable the cultivation of grassland or rangeland, which are one of the main sources of food for cattles.
column30: Raising of cattel and buffaloes often depends on indigenous and local communities' knowledge, which can inform the management of said species, for example locally adapted breeds.
column31: In some locations, cultural knowledge including ecological knowledge can inform the management of livestock.

column5: Raising of horses and other equines
column8: Animal production is dependent on the ecosystem contributions' to livestock provisioning. Raising of horses and other equines also requires biomass for many functions, such as plant and animal-based materials for feed and bedding.
column9: Raising of horses and other equines depends on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to treat large quantities of manure, other solid wastes, and wastewater, mitigating their harmful effects.
column10: Raising of horses and other equines is dependent on soil and sediment retention for maintenance of soils, preventing fertiliser run-off, and preventing or limiting exposed topsoil from being blown away by wind or washed away by rain. It also depends on landslide mitigation as the mass movement of soil and rock could damage the pastures, buildings and other infrastructure.
column11: Livestock agriculture is dependent on water purification by ecosystems to maintain or improve the quality of the water accessible to the animals as well as to break down or remove any pollutants emitted in the agricultural process.
column12: Raising of horses and other equines is dependent on healthy and fertile soils to provide plant nutrition and health for the production of pastural crops and feedstocks.
column13: Raising of horses is dependent on atmospheric and ecosystem-based dilution to disperse and reduce the impact of pollution on the animals, and also to disperse and reduce the impact of pollutants from the production on the ecosystems (e.g. nitrogent from horse manure in groundwater).
column14: Raising of horses and other equines is dependent on biological control, to control pests which irritate or impact the health of equines. Pastural and feedstock crops fed to horses and equines are also dependent on any disease control naturally afforded.
column15: Raising of horses and other equines can generate air pollution for example nitrogen from horse manure, depending on air filtration by ecosystems to mitigate or reduce the harmful impacts of the activity.
column16: Raising of horses and other equinesis is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect animals, buildings and infrastructure from flooding.
column17: Raising of horses and other equines depends on the provision of genetic material to enable selective breeding which is central to almost all livestock farming.
column18: Raising of horses and other equines depends on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions necessary for cultivation of grassland or rangeland for animal feed, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage infrastructure.
column19: Raising of horses and other equines depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for animals to drink, for washing animals and for cleaning yards and parlours.
column20: Maintenance of a natural gene pool is important to maintain desirable genetic traits and variation in horses.
column21: Raising of horses could depend on noise attenuation to reduce horses exposure to external noise, for welfare and safety.
column22: Horse farmers might recruit shelterbelts and other cover crops/vegetation to act as a visual screen or a barrier to dust arising as a result of farming.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of animal production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for raising animals (e.g. forests and bodies of water can reduce local temperature, reducing heat stress for animals).
column25: Livestock production is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect animals, buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms. For example, the use of vegetation for livestock shelter is common in upland farming, whereby the provision of shelter provides a lifeline for cattle during storms.
column26: Livestock production depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient flow of water even during drier seasons (e.g. for animals to drink, cleaning and sanitation) and to mitigate peak flows that could flood the pastures, builsings or associated infrastructure.
column27: Raising of horses and other equines is dependent on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to enable the cultivation of grassland, which are one of the main sources of food for horses.

column3: Fishing and aquaculture
column8: Aquaculture is dependent on the ecosystem contributions' to the growth of animals and plants (e.g. fish, shellfish, seaweed) in aquaculture facilities that are harvested for various uses. Aquaculture also requires plant and animal-based materials for feedstock to support the development of fish and other products. Natural fiber-based materials are also used, for example ropes.
column9: Aquaculture depends on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to break down water contaminants as well as waste and leachates from the production.
column10: Aquaculture relies on soil and sediment retention for protection of the areas where aquaculture farms are located as well as for retention of the sediment and water qualities necessary for aquaculture production.
column11: Aquaculture depends on water purification by ecosystems to provide clean and safe conditions to rear fish and other products and to minimise the impacts resulting from wastes generated from fish farms.
column12: Aquaculture is dependent on the maintenance of soil quality in order to maintain net productivity.
column13: Aquaculture is dependent on bio-physico chemical processes to dilute, breakdown, and lessen the potential negative impacts of pollutants and other compounds in the natural environment, and those resulting from aquacultural production, in order to provide clean and safe conditions to rear fish and other products, and to minimise the impacts resulting from wastes generated from fish and other species farms.
column14: Aquaculture depends on biological control to reduce disesases exacerbated due to often high concentrations of fish, through the use of bacteria and bacteriophages as biological agents for disease control. Most disease in aquaculture is as a result of stress caused by poor husbandry practices. This can be ameliorated through increased water quality for example, and disease control could help reduce the disease symptoms.
column15: The filtering of pollutants and its mitigation effects in the air contribute to good conditions for healthy fish populations. Aquaculture can also generate air pollution, for example from wastes generated from fish farms, depending on air filtration by ecosystems to mitigate or reduce the harmful impacts of the activity in order to provide clean and safe conditions to rear fish and other products.
column16: Both marine and freshwater aquaculture is susceptible to flood damage. As such, it is dependent on coastal protection and river flood mitigation services provided by riparian vegetation or seascape elements such as kelp beds, mangroves, sand bars etc.
column17: Aquaculture is dependent upon the effective management of the genetic resources for farmed aquatic plants and farmed fish, as well as those for the organisms that provide their food and ecosystem services.
column18: Aquaculture depends on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions necessary for its activities, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could affect the cultivation of aquatic organisms, buildings or infrastructure.
column19: Aquaculture depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, for activities such as filling fish tanks.
column20: Aquaculture is dependent on nursery populations that protect natural gene pools for valuable traits and maintain healthy habitats that enable the continued reproduction of species.
column21: ND
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of aquaculture activities. They are vital to enabling their operation and ensuring their productivity (e.g. stabilising temperature - which also helps maintain the appropriate water chemistry, regulating local humidity).
column25: Aquaculture is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services from kelp beds, mangroves, sand bars etc. to protect activities and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Aquacultures depend on the provision of water flow to enable sufficient flow through during the dry seasons. Additionally, it is important to refresh dissolved oxygen levels, flush waste products and to a lesser extent deliver food supplies.
column27: Aquaculture depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to provide good conditions for its productivity.

column3: Fishing and aquaculture
column8: Fishing depends on the ecosystem contributions' to provide biomass such as wild fish, crustaceans, molluscs, aquatic animals and other freshwater and marine materials or organisms regulating population dynamics and nutrient availability, that are captured, primarily for food production.
column9: Fishing depends on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to break down water contaminants (e.g. microorganisms mitigate the impacts of heavy metal pollutants) as well as waste and leachates from the production.
column10: Fishing is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide good river quality and healthy fish. Riverine fishing is safer if the riverbanks are stable.
column11: Fishing is dependent on water purification ecosystem services for ensuring the quality and availability of water for a healthy and diverse population of fish.
column12: Fishing relies on the maintenance of healthy soil and nutrient cycling for appropriate water conditions for freshwater fish species.
column13: Fishing is dependent on atmospheric and ecosystem-based dilution to disperse and reduce the impact of pollution on the animals.
column14: Fishing is dependent on the natural biological control of algae, macrophytes and diseases to preserve fish stocks.
column15: The filtering of pollutants and its mitigation effects in the air contribute to good conditions for healthy fish populations.
column16: Fishing is dependent on flood mitigation services to safeguard fish populations from flooding and ensure the safety of riverine fishing.
column17: Fishing depends on the provision of genetic materials to maintain healthy fish stocks and species and ecosystem biodiversity.
column18: Fishing activities are dependent on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events (e.g. buffer sea level change, floodings, storm impacts) that could impact fishing reproduction or the ability to continuing fishing activities.
column19: Fishing depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient water depth, stream flow and quality of water.
column20: Fishing is dependent on nursery populations that protect natural gene pools for valuable traits and maintain healthy habitats that enable the continued reproduction of species.
column21: ND
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the fishing locations to support healthy fish stocks and productive fishing activities (e.g. stabilising temperature - which also helps maintain the appropriate water chemistry, regulating local humidity). and properties (e.g. temperature, dissolved oxygen, pH, biological oxygen demand, ammonia, nitrate, and other compounds). The degree of dependence on local climate regulation varies across different fish species and the physical and climatological preconditions.
column25: Fishing activities are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to safeguard infrastructure from the effects of wind, sand, and other storms.
column26: Fishing is dependent on water flow regulation because it relies on the provision of water flow to enable stream flow and supply.
column27: Fishing depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure the quality of the river such as flow and water characteristics which can influence fish stocks.
column30: Fishing is dependent on the provision of scientific and educational information acquired from nature (e.g. understanding ecosystem indicators for fish health, recovery and resilience, and environmental recorders).
column31: In some locations, cultural knowledge including ecological knowledge can inform fishing practices.

column3: Forestry and logging
column7: Gathering of non-wood forest products and plants in the wild can use animals for transport between sites.
column8: Ecosystems provide wild growing materials such as mushrooms, truffles, berries, nuts, balata and other rubber-like gums, cork, lac and resins, balsams, vegetable hair, eelgrass, acorns, horse chestnuts, and mosses and lichens, that are captured and harvested.
column9: Gathering of non-wood forest products depends on solid waste remediation to transform organic substances and provide good conditions for the growth of the forest and the non-wood forest products.
column10: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for the forest area.
column11: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on water purification ecosystem services for ensuring the quality and availability of water for growth of the forest and non-wood forest products within it.
column12: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on fertile soils for the growing of mushrooms, berries, nuts, acorns and other non-wood forest products.
column14: Gathering of non-wood forest products depend on biological control to maintain conditions of non-wood forest products and to reduce diseases.
column15: Gathering of non-wood forest products depends on air filtration by ecosystems for the maintenance of air quality for the health of the forest.
column16: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect the forest areas of flooding, which helps maintain suitable conditions for forest growth and growth of non-wood forest products.
column17: Gathering of non-wood forest products benefits from genetic diversity.
column18: Gathering of non-wood forest products depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change for forest growth and growth of the non-wood forest products. Global climate change regulation also reduces the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the forest.
column19: Gathering non-wood forest products depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, for tree growth and growth of the non-wood forest products.
column20: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on the maintenance of habitats and natural gene pools which sustain the populations of species which are gathered, such as mushrooms, berries, nuts, and other non-wood forest products and plants.
column21: N/A
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of forests (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for growth of trees and non-wood forest products.
column24: Gathering non-wood forest products depends on pollination, as the activity includes gathering of forest fruits that are insect pollinated.
column25: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect forests and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Gathering of non-wood forest products depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the forest areas and infrastructure. The regulation of water flows helps ensure sufficient water supply even during dry periods, e.g. reducing fire risk.
column27: Gathering of non-wood forest products is dependent on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure sufficient levels of rainfall for growth and well-being of forests and forests products.
column31: In some locations, cultural value of species conservation. Some forests are deemed to be culturally or spiritually significant.

column3: Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities
column5: Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds
column7: Horses, mules, oxen and other animals are used as sources of draught power for various purposes such as pulling agricultural implements and pumping irrigation water.
column8: Growing of cereals, leguminous crops and oil seeds depends on the ecosystem to produce biomass materials, that are captured and harvested in uncultivated production contexts. The activity also depends on the ecosystem contributions to the growth of organic material, as well as waste, and compost.
column9: Non-perennial agriculture is dependent on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to break down soil contaminants as well as waste and leachates from the production.
column10: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on erosion control provided by ecosystems, which reduces the loss of soil and runoff of fertilisers from the cultivation sites. It also depends on landslide mitigation as the mass movement of soil and rock could damage the cultivation site and areas around it.
column11: Growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on water purification ecosystem services for ensuring the quality and availability of water for the cultivation and reducing the agricultural production's impact on water quality.
column12: Healthy and fertile soils generated by bio-geochemical decomposition are critical for growing of non-perennial crops.
column13: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on the atmosphere and ecosystems to dilute water pollutants generated through the agricultural production.
column14: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on the biological control that insects, birds, and small mammals provide, as a natural solution for controlling pests such as aphids, to protect crops.
column15: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on air filtration by ecosystems as crop production benefits from good air quality and reduced ozone damage.
column16: The cultivation of non-perennial crops is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect crops, buildings, and infrastructure from flooding.
column17: Growing perennial crops depends on the provision of genetic materials, for example to enable scientists and breeders to cross modern crops with their wild relatives to reintroduce desirable genetic traits such as disease resistance or drought tolerance.
column18: Growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions necessary for the given crops, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the cultivation site, buildings or infrastructure.
column19: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water to grow the crops and for general on-farm use (such as cleaning, sanitation, crop spraying).
column20: The growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on the maintenance of natural gene pools for valuable traits.
column21: N/A
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of agricultural production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for growing crops.
column24: Cultivation of many non-perennial crops is dependent on pollination services carried out by birds, bats and insects, such as bumblebees, hoverflies, honey bees and moths.
column25: The cultivation of non-perennial crops is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect crops, buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms (e.g. agricultural producers can use cover crops or other canopy cover to protect the cultivation sites from wind).
column26: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient flow of water even during drier seasons (e.g. for irrigation, cleaning and sanitation) and to mitigate peak flows that could flood the cultivation sites or associated infrastructure.
column27: Growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure sufficient levels of rainfall for productive cultivation.

column9: Growing of other non-perennial crops is dependent on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to break down soil contaminants as well as waste and leachates from the production.

column11: Growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on water purification ecosystem services for ensuring the quality and availability of water for the cultivation and reducing the agricultural production's impact on water quality.
column12: Healthy and fertile soils generated by bio-geochemical decomposition are critical for growing of non-perennial crops.
column13: Growing of other non-perennial crops depends on atmosphere and the ecosystems to maintain air and water quality.
column14: Growing of other non-perennial crops depends on the biological control that insects, birds, and small mammals provide, as a natural solution for destroying pests such as aphids, to protect crops, making it essential for successful cultivation.
column15: Growing of non-perennial crops depends on air filtration by ecosystems as crop production benefits from good air quality.
column16: Growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect crops, buildings, and infrastructure from flooding.
column17: Growing of other non-perennial crops depends on the provision of genetic materials to enable scientists and breeders to seek to cross modern crops with their wild relatives to reintroduce desirable genetic traits such as disease resistance or drought tolerance.
column18: Growing of other non-perennial crops are dependent on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions necessary for the given crops, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the cultivation site, buildings or infrastructure.
column19: Growing of other non-perennial crops depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water to grow the crops and for general on-farm use (such as cleaning, sanitation, crop spraying).
column20: Non-perennial crops are dependent on natural gene pools for valuable traits.
column21: N/A
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of agricultural production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for growing crops.
column24: The growth of many non-perennial crops is dependent on pollination services carried out by birds, bats and insects, such as bumblebees, hoverflies, honey bees and moths.
column25: Growing of other non-perennial crops depends on storm mitigation ecosystem services, utilizing shelterbelts, cover crops, plantations, forests, or any canopy cover to protect crops, buildings, and infrastructure from wind, sand, and other storm impacts, including floods.
column26: Growing of other non-perennial crops depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient flow of water even during drier seasons (e.g. for irrigation, cleaning and sanitation) and to mitigate peak flows that could flood the cultivation sites or associated infrastructure.
column27: Growing of non-perennial crops is dependent on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure sufficient levels of rainfall for productive cultivation.

column3: Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities
column4: Hunting, trapping and related service activities
column7: These activities are dependent on hunting and capture of animals, including for the purposes of using these as a source of energy. Animals can also be used during the hunting, trapping and related services activities for transport.
column8: Biomass provisioning plays a crucial role in determining the abundance and health of target species that are hunted. The availability of biomass directly affects the viability of hunting, as it determines the number of animals that can be harvested and the potential for economic returns.
column9: Hunting and trapping and related service activities depend on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to transform organic waste products. This reduces the need for human-made removal of the solid waste.
column10: Hunting, trapping and related service activities are dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for the ecosystems that provide natural habitats to species as well as for infrastructure.
column11: N/A
column13: Hunting, trapping and related service activities depend on atmosphere and the ecosystems to maintain air and water quality.
column14: Hunting, trapping and related service activities depends on the biological control that insects, birds, and small mammals provide, as a natural solution for destroying pests.
column15: Hunting, trapping and related service activities depends on air filtration by ecosystems to maintain air quality.
column16: Hunting, trapping and related service activities are dependent on flood mitigation services to protect the habitats of the animals and to protect any infrastructure from flooding.
column18: ND
column19: Hunting and related activities depend on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water. Water sources such as rivers and wetlands provide essential habitats for many wildlife species including game species that are targeted for hunting and trapping.
column20: Hunting, trapping and related service activities is dependent on the maintenance of habitats and natural gene pools which sustain the populations of species hunted.
column21: N/A
column23: ND
column25: Hunting, trapping and related service activities are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect animals and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Hunting, trapping and related services depend on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the habitats of animals.
column27: The success rate of hunting can be dependent on the weather conditions including rainfall.
column28: Hunting and trapping can be recreational activities enjoyed by individuals and communities, often with cultural or historical significance. Hunting and trapping are therefore dependent on recreation related services. The availability of these services directly influences the opportunities for these activities, providing a connection to nature and traditions.

column3: Forestry and logging
column7: Animals used for transporting timber (e.g. timber harvested under low impact schemes) as well as gathering of fire wood.
column8: Logging depends on the biomass provisioning service because ecosystems contribute to the growth of trees and other woody biomass in both cultivated (plantation) and uncultivated production contexts that can be harvested.
column9: Logging depends on solid waste remediation processes to transform organic waste products. This reduces the need for human-made removal of the solid waste, which could result in disturbances to the forest area.
column10: Logging activities are dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for the forest area and infrastructure.
column11: N/A
column12: The depth and quality of soil influence the rate at which trees grow and accumulate biomass, which in turn provides more healthy forests that can resist damage from catastrophic events like acute insect and disease attacks, fire, wind, and flooding, and fully recover from these perturbations.
column14: Logging depends on biological pest control to enable the maintenance of wood condition, and to reduce diseases, for example diseases affecting commercial trees in the northern hemisphere.
column15: Logging depends on air filtration provided by ecosystems to mitigate the harmful effects of air pollutants released.
column16: Logging activities are dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from flooding and for the maintenance of conditions for tree growth.
column18: ND
column19: Logging uses a significant amount of water for transporting logs, cleaning equipment, and fire suppression.
column21: Vegetation can act as a noise barrier, reducing the impact of noise pollution from logging.
column22: Logging is one of the main drivers of road construction in forests. The surrounding nature can help mitigate the visual impacts of roads and other logging activities.
column23: N/A
column25: Logging is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect forests and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Logging depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the forest areas and infrastructure.
column27: N/A

column3: Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities

column8: Mixed farming is dependent on the ecosystem's capacity to provide biomass. Other biomass such as organic matter, waste and compost, is also used in mixed farming.

column14: Mixed farming depends on the biological control that insects, birds, and small mammals provide, as a natural solution for destroying pests such as aphids, to protect crops, making it essential for successful cultivation.
column15: Mixed farming depends on air filtration by ecosystems to maintain air quality, as air pollutants can cause damage to plants which impacts the yield.

column17: Growing crops depends on the provision of genetic materials to enable scientists and breeders to seek to cross modern crops with their wild relatives to reintroduce desirable genetic traits such as disease resistance or drought tolerance.

column19: Mixed farming depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water to grow grass and crops, sustain livestock, and for general on-farm use (such as cleaning, sanitation, crop spraying).

column21: N/A
column23: Mixed farming depends on the capacity of ecosystems to regulate the microclimate in the locations of agricultural production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for growing crops.
column24: Successful mixed farming depends on the presence of pollinators such as birds, bats and insects, such as bumblebees, hoverflies, honey bees and moths in the landscape.
column25: Mixed farming is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect crops, animals, buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Mixed farming depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient flow of water even during drier seasons (e.g. for irrigation, cleaning and sanitation) and to mitigate peak flows that could flood the cultivation sites or associated infrastructure.

column15: Some seed processing activities (e.g. treatment of seeds) generate air pollution, and therefore depend on air filtration by ecosystems to mitigate or reduce the harmful impacts of the activity and maintain air quality.
column16: Seed processing activities are dependent on flood mitigation services to protect crops, buildings, and infrastructure from flooding.
column17: Seed processing for propagation depends on the provision of genetic materials to enable scientists and breeders to seek to cross modern crops with their wild relatives to reintroduce desirable genetic traits such as disease resistance or drought tolerance.
column18: Seed processing activities are dependent on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the buildings or infrastructure.
column19: Seed processing depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for cleaning and treatment of seeds. Water is also needed for cleaning and sanitation of the facilities.
column21: N/A
column23: Seed processing activities depend on ecosystems to regulate the micro climate in the location of the activities. This improves the conditions for storing and processing of the seeds (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), reducing the need for human-made cooling or humidity controls.
column24: The activity is the resultant of the intermediary service of pollination by birds, bats and insects, such as bumblebees, hoverflies, honey bees and moths.
column25: Seed processing for propagation is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Seed processing activities depend on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the seeds, buildings and infrastructure. The regulation of water flows helps ensure sufficient water supply even during dry periods, e.g. for seed cleaning.
column27: Seed processing for propagation depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure availability of water for cleaning and treatment of seeds.
column30: Seed processing for propagation can be informed by knowledge regarding the management of certain agricultural products.

column13: Support activities for crop production depends on the atmosphere and ecosystems to dilute water pollutants generated through the activity to meet water quality standards.
column14: Support activities for crop production depend on the biological control that insects, birds, and small mammals provide, as a natural solution for destroying pests such as aphids, to protect crops, making it essential for successful cultivation.
column15: Some support activities for crop production (e.g. preparation of fields, crop spraying) generate air pollution, and therefore depend on air filtration by ecosystems to mitigate or reduce the harmful impacts of the activity and maintain air quality.

column17: Support activities for crop production depend on the provision of genetic materials to enable scientists and breeders to seek to cross modern crops with their wild relatives to reintroduce desirable genetic traits such as disease resistance or drought tolerance.
column18: Support activities for crop production are dependent on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions necessary for the given plants, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the cultivation site, buildings or infrastructure.
column19: Support activities for crop production depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for preparation of fields, crop spraying and other activities.
column21: N/A
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of agricultural production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, and regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for growing crops.
column24: The activity is the resultant of the intermediary service of pollination by birds, bats and insects, such as bumblebees, hoverflies, honey bees and moths.
column25: Support activities for crop production are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect crops, buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Support activities for crop production depend on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. column3: Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities
column4: Support activities to agriculture and post-harvest crop activities
column8: Support activities for animal production such as growth of animals, stud services and farm animal boarding and care require biomass for many functions, such as plant and animal based materials for feed and bedding.
column9: Support activities for animal production such as coop cleaning, sheep shearing of animals, stud services and farm animal boarding and care depends on solid waste remediation by ecosystems (e.g. micro-organisms, algae, plants and animals) to treat large quantities of manure, droppings, wool, other solid wastes, and wastewater, mitigating their harmful effects.
column10: Support activities for animal production is dependent on soil and sediment retention for maintenance of soils, preventing fertiliser run-off, and preventing or limiting exposed topsoil from being blown away by wind or washed away by rain. It also depends on landslide mitigation as the mass movement of soil and rock could damage the pastures, buildings and other infrastructure.
column11: Support activities for animal production is dependent on water purification by ecosystems to maintain or improve the quality of the water accessible to the animals as well as to break down or remove any pollutants emitted in the agricultural process.
column12: Support activities for animal production is dependent on healthy and fertile soils to provide plant nutrition and health for the growth and output of animals.
column13: Support activities for animal production is dependent on atmospheric and ecosystem-based dilution to disperse and reduce the impact of pollution on the animals, and also to disperse and reduce the impact of pollutants on the ecosystems.
column14: Support activities for animal production is dependent on biological control, to control pests which irritate or impact the health of animals.
column15: Support activities for animal production depends on air filtration by ecosystems to reduce the impact of, and disperse air pollutants.
column16: Support activities for animal production is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect animals, buildings and infrastructure from flooding.
column17: Support activities for animal production, especially those related to activities related to artificial insemination, stud services, etc. depend on the provision of genetic material to enable selective breeding which is central to almost all livestock farming.
column18: Support activities for animal production depends on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, maintain the climatic conditions, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage infrastructure.
column19: Support activities for animal production depend on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for animals to drink, for washing animals and for cleaning coops, yards and parlours.
column20: Maintenance of natural gene pool is important to maintain desirable genetic traits and variation in cattle and other animals.
column21: Support activities for animal production could depend on noise attenuation to reduce animal exposure to external noise, for welfare and safety. Shelterbelts and other cover crops/vegetation could act as a visual screen or a barrier to noise as a result of cattle, sheep, poultry or other animals.
column22: Support activities for animal production might use  shelterbelts and other cover crops/vegetation to act as a visual screen or a barrier to dust arising as a result of cattle, sheep, poultry or other animals.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of animal production (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), providing stable conditions for raising animals (e.g. forests and bodies of water can reduce local temperature, reducing heat stress for animals).
column25: Support activities for animal production is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect animals, buildings, and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms. For example, the use of vegetation for livestock shelter is common in upland farming and facilities, whereby the provision of shelter provides a lifeline for cattle during storms.
column26: Support activities for animal production depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient flow of water even during drier seasons (e.g. for animals to drink, cleaning and sanitation) and to mitigate peak flows that could flood the pastures, builsings or associated infrastructure.
column27: Support activities for animal production is dependent on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at farms and facilities.
column30: Support activities for animal production can be informed by indigenous and local communities' knowledge regarding the management of certain agricultural products.

column3: Forestry and logging

column18: Support services to forestry depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could prevent operation activities such as transportation of logs and timber evaluation.
column19: Support services for forestry rely on the water supply services provided by ecosystems, which ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, curbing the spread of dangerous wildfires and facilitating general on-farm use and office building operations.

column27: Support services to forestry depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the fire risk.

column3: Extraction of crude petroleum and natural gas
column9: Extraction of crude petroleum depends on solid waste remediation as they benefit from assimilation services (e.g. dilution and microbial action), which help break down and disperse oil and chemicals.
column10: Extraction of crude petroleum is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure.
column11: Extraction of petroleum depends on water purification by ecosystems to improve quality of water and reduce the need for water treatment, especially for processes such as cooling and steam generation.
column13: Extraction of crude petroleum depends on the atmosphere and ecosystems to help break down and disperse oil and chemicals.
column15: Assimilation services (e.g. dilution and microbial action) help break down and disperse oil and chemicals to maintain air quality.
column16: The extraction of crude petroleum is dependent on flood mitigation services to safeguard infrastructure from flooding. This can be provided by surrounding vegetation, which helps to ensure continued access.
column18: Crude petroleum extraction sites depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage buildings and infrastructure or affect extraction operations.
column19: Extraction of crude petroleum depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, for general operations, cooling, controlling fires, and for desalination processes.
column21: Petroleum extraction involves the use of heavy machinery and equipment that can generate high levels of noise, which can be harmful to workers and nearby communities. Ecosystems (e.g., vegetation) can act as a noise barrier, reducing the impact of this noise pollution.
column22: Ecosystems can reduce the impact of smell and visual pollution from the extraction of crude petroleum.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the location of petroleum extraction activities (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels). More stable local climate supports smooth operation and extends the lifetime of facilities and infrastructure.
column25: Extraction of crude petroleum is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Extraction of crude petroleum depends on water flow regulation to enable the control of oil spills and leaks that can contaminate water sources and disrupt water flow.
column27: ND

column3: Other mining and quarrying
column8: Ecosystems provide biomass which can be used to provide energy for mining and quarrying operations. The energy is typically provided by fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas. However, biomass is a renewable resource that can be used to generate electricity, heat, and steam.
column9: Mining and quarrying depends on solid waste remediation to reduce the harmful effects of potential toxic effluents in water and solid waste, which are needed during the mining process.
column10: Mines rely on sources of natural erosion control, such as vegetation cover, to protect roads and infrastructure at the mine site.
column11: Mining and quarrying are dependent on water purification by ecosystems to uphold the chemical composition of water necessary for the detoxification of potential effluents, and other critical stages throughout the production process.
column13: Mining and quarrying depends on the atmosphere and ecosystems to dilute pollution produced on site (e.g., by chimneys) or by nearby industries.
column15: Mining and quarrying n.e.c. depends on air filtration by ecosystems such as natural or planted vegetation to mitigate or reduce harmful impacts, and to protect worker health and safety.
column16: Mining and quarrying activities are dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from flooding.
column18: Mining and quarrying depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage buildings and infrastructure or affect the ability to continue operations.
column19: Mines depend on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, for haul road dust suppression, washdown areas and to recharge the backfilled pit voids with groundwater as mining progresses.
column21: Ecosystems (e.g., vegetation) can act as a noise barrier, reducing the impact of noise pollution from the process of mining and quarrying, helping to mitigate its harmful or stressful effects.
column22: Ecosystems can reduce the impact of smells from mining and quarrying.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the location of mining activities (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels). More stable local climate supports smooth operation and extends the lifetime of facilities and infrastructure. Stable local temperature is particularly critical for certain chemical processes.
column25: Mining and quarrying are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect mines and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Mining activities depend on water flow maintenance for various processes. Water flow is vital for cooling and cracking chemicals.
column27: Mining and quarrying depend on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at mining sites, and to ensure sufficient water supply that may be needed for cooling systems or the production of steam.

column27: Mining of non-ferrous metal ores depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at manufacturing sites, and to ensure sufficient water supply that may be needed for cooling systems or the production of steam.

column4: Quarrying of stone, sand and clay
column7: Certain animals (e.g., oxen, donkeys and camels) are used as draught animals for transporting of stone, sand and clay using carts.
column8: Ecosystems provide biomass which can be used to provide energy for mining operations. The energy is typically provided by fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas. However, biomass is a renewable resource that can be used to generate electricity, heat, and steam.

column22: Ecosystems can reduce the impact of smells from mining and quarrying.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the location of mining activities (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels). More stable local climate supports smooth operation and extends the lifetime of facilities and infrastructure. Stable local temperature is particularly critical for certain chemical processes.
column25: Mining and quarrying are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect mines and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.

column27: Mining and quarrying depend on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at mining sites, and to ensure sufficient water supply that may be needed for cooling systems or the production of steam.

column27: Manufacturing of paper and paper products depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at manufacturing sites, and to secure water supply.

column19: The manufacturing process depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for processes such as surface treatment and coating, paint spray booths, washing, rinsing, hosing, cooling, air-conditioning systems and boilers.
column21: Vegetation mitigates the noise from the manufacturing sites, helping to mitigate its harmful or stressful effects.
column22: For some manufacturing sites, ecosystems can reduce the impact of smells and visual pollution from the manufacture of motorcycles.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of manufacturing facilities, enabling their operation and operation of associated infrastructure (e.g. stabilising local temperature, humidity and regulating winds).
column25: Manufacture of motorcycles is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect manufacturing sites and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Manufacturing sites are dependent on water flow regulation to mitigate the risk of floods and damage. Some manufacturing processes included in this economic activity rely on water, and therefore the ecosystem's ability to regulate and sustain water flow.
column27: Manufacturing of transport equipment depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at manufacturing sites.

column4: Manufacture of wiring and wiring devices
column9: Manufacture of wiring depend on remediation services to mitigate the harmful effects of the solid waste such as metal shavings, sludge, and wastewater, generated by the production processes, involving materials like copper, aluminum, and rare earth metals. This ecosystem service can mitigate the harmful effects of hazardous waste.
column10: Manufacture of wiring and wiring devices is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure.
column11: Manufacture of wiring and wiring devices is dependent on water purification by ecosystems to uphold the chemical composition of water necessary for cooling purposes, detoxification of potential effluents, and other critical stages throughout the production process.

column19: Manufacture of wiring depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, for the cooling of the wires after they have been lazered to be checked for consistency.
column21: The manufacture of wires and wiring devices may involve noise-generating processes such as machining, cutting, grinding, and testing.  Vegetation can act as a noise barrier, reducing the impact of noise pollution.
column22: For some manufacturing sites, ecosystems can reduce the impact of smell and visual pollution from the manufacture of wiring and wiring devices.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of manufacturing facilities, enabling their operation and operation of associated infrastructure (e.g. stabilising local temperature, humidity and regulating winds).
column25: Manufacture of wiring and wiring devices is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect manufacturing sites and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: The manufacture of electronics equipment depends on the provision of a stable water supply to support the entire production process.
column27: Manufacture of wiring and wiring devices depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at manufacturing sites, and to ensure sufficient water supply that may be needed for cooling systems or the production of steam.

column23: If using a building, repair activities depend on ecosystems to regulate the micro climate in the location of the building (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels). This improves the conditions, reduces the cost of using the building and prevents damage to the equipment (e.g. high temperatures can cause equipment to overheat and malfunction, while high humidity can lead to corrosion and other forms of damage).

column16: Sawmilling and planing of wood depend on flood mitigation services to protect manufacturing sites and other infrastructure from flooding.
column18: Manufacturing sites depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the buildings and infrastructure or affect the manufacturing processes.
column19: The activity depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, as water supply is crucial for consumption, sanitation, cleaning, and maintenance.
column21: Vegetation forms a natural noise reduction structure to mediate noise impacts from sawmilling and planing of wood.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of manufacturing facilities, enabling their operation and operation of associated infrastructure (e.g. stabilising local temperature, humidity and regulating winds).
column25: Sawmilling and planing of wood are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect facilities and infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Manufacturing plants are dependent on water flow regulation for managing stormwater runoff and preventing flooding which can cause damage to property, reduce the quality of life, and pose risks to human safety
column27: Manufacturing plants depend on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at manufacturing sites.

column3: Manufacture of textiles
column4: Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles
column9: Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles produces organic and inorganic solid waste that ecosystems transform to mitigate their harmful effects.
column10: Manufacture of textiles is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure.
column11: Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles are dependent on water purification by ecosystems/organisms to maintain or improve the quality of the water used for the cleaning and processing of raw material (such as wool), or during the later stages of processing.
column13: Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles depends on the local atmosphere and ecosystems for the dilution of pollution.
column15: Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles can generate air pollution, depending on air filtration by ecosystems to mitigate or reduce the harmful impacts of the activity, maintain air quality and detoxify potential effluent in solid waste.
column16: Manufacture of textiles depends on flood mitigation services to protect manufacturing sites and other infrastructure from flooding.
column18: Manufacturing of textile sites depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the buildings and infrastructure or affect the manufacturing processes
column19: Textile manufacture depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water. All fibers have significant water demands including cleaning and processing of raw material, or during the later stages of processing.
column21: Vegetation mitigates the noise from texitile processing, helping to mitigate its harmful or stressful effects.
column22: Ecosystems can mediate dust and smell impacts and minimise the escape and spread of substances hazardous to health, generated by spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of manufacturing facilities, enabling their operation and operation of associated infrastructure (e.g. stabilising local temperature, humidity and regulating winds).
column25: Manufacture of textiles is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect manufacturing sites and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Manufacturing textiles requires vast amount of water, in various stages of spinning, dyeing, washing.
column27: Manufacturing of textile depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to mitigate the risk of floods and damages at manufacturing sites.
column30: Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles from natural products could depend on scientific knowledge and education on different properties of natural materials.

column9: Fossil fuels energy production depends on solid waste remediation, specifically assimilation services (e.g. dilution and microbial action) to help break down and disperse oil and chemicals.
column10: Fossil fuels energy production is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure.
column11: Fossil fuel energy production is dependent on water purification to remove substances (e.g., strontium and radionuclides) through filtration, distillation, and vaporisation.
column15: Fossil fuels energy production depends on air filtration and assimilation services provided by ecosystems (e.g. dilution) to help break down and disperse oil and chemicals.
column16: Fossil fuels energy production is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from flooding.
column18: Fossil fuels energy production facilities depend on global climate regulation to maintain a relatively steady climate and to mitigate and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage buildings and infrastructure. Increased temperatures and extreme weather can also affect operations.
column19: Fossil fuels energy production depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure a sufficient quantity of water for cooling systems, industrial washing, sanitary use, operations and to control fires.
column21: Ecosystems (e.g., vegetation) can act as a noise barrier, reducing the impact of noise pollution from fossil fuel production activities.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of fossil fuel power stations (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), reducing the cost of using buildings or infrastructure and extending their lifetime.
column25: Fossil fuels energy production is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect production sites and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Fossil fuel energy production activities depend on the provision of water flow regulation to enable the use of water for routine operations (e.g., cooling systems and controlling fires).

column9: Nuclear power production depends on solid waste remediation to remove pollutants and break down substances.
column10: Nuclear power production is dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure.
column11: Nuclear power plants rely on efficient filtration of water to operate reliably for several components, such as moderator, to slow down neutrons released from fission; coolants; steam generation systems; and reactor clean up.
column13: Nuclear energy production depends on ecosystems to dilute chemical, radiative and thermal discharges.
column15: Nuclear power production depends on air filtration by ecosystems to filter pollutants.
column16: Nuclear power production is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from flooding. The safety of nuclear power plants can be seriously affected by flooding, both for sites on rivers and for sites on the sea coast (including enclosed and semi-enclosed water bodies) or large lakes
column18: Nuclear power production facilities depend on global climate regulation to maintain a relatively steady climate and to mitigate and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage buildings and infrastructure. Increased temperatures and extreme weather can also affect operations.
column19: Energy production depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure a sufficient quantity of water, which is used to cool thermal nuclear generation plants.
column21: Ecosystems (e.g., vegetation) can act as a noise barrier, reducing the impact of noise pollution from nuclear power production.
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of nuclear power stations (e.g. stabilising local temperatures, regulating local humidity levels), reducing the cost of using buildings or infrastructure and extending their lifetime. Higher temperatures can result in a negative impact on the capacity of cooling the safety systems ensuring evacuation of reactor power.
column25: Nuclear energy production is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect production sites and other infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Nuclear power production activities depend on the provision of water flow regulation to enable the use of water for routine operations.

column9: Steam and air conditioning supply depend on solid waste remediation to detoxify water used in the production of steam and hot water.
column10: Steam and air conditioning supply are dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for production plants and other infrastructure.
column11: Steam and air conditioning supply activities are dependent on water purification by ecosystems to maintain or improve the quality of the water used for producing ice, hot water and steam.
column13: Steam and air conditioning supply require clean sanitation, which is provided by the atmosphere and ecosystems through dilution.
column15: Steam and air conditioning supply depends on air filtration by ecosystems since naturally filtered air helps protect human health and the environment.
column16: Steam and air conditioning supply activities are dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from flooding.
column18: Steam and air conditioning supply facilities depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage buildings and infrastructure or affect operations.
column19: Steam and air conditioning supply depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure a sufficient quantity of water, which is used to cool thermal generation plants and drive steam turbines.

column9: N/A

column11: ND

column18: Sale, maintenance and repair of motorcycles facilities depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage the buildings and infrastructure.

column22: Ecosystems can reduce the impact of smell and visual pollution from the sale, maintenance and repair of motorcycles and related parts and accessories.

column27: Sale, maintenance and repair of motorcycles depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure availability of water for cleaning and maintenance of the sale facilities.

column3: Postal and courier activities
column9: ND
column10: Soil and sediment retention provides a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure such as roads, railways and airfields used during courier activities.
column11: ND
column15: ND
column16: Courier activities are dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms and enable uninterrupted operation.
column18: Courier activities depend on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, and to reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage infrastructure or impact the efficiency of transportation operations.
column19: Courier activities depend on the provision of water supply services ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water for activities such as cleaning vehicle and equipment.
column21: N/A
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of courier activities, ensuring appropriate conditions for the activities (e.g. green spaces reduce urban heat) and enabling operation of the necessary infrastructure (e.g. stabilising local temperature, humidity and regulating winds).
column25: Courier activities are dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to protect infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms and enable uninterrupted operation.
column26: Courrier activities depend on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the buildings and infrastructure. The regulation of water flows helps ensure sufficient water supply even during dry periods, which is needed for cleaning and maintenance (e.g. of vehicles).
column27: Courrier activities depend on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure the availability of water for cleaning and maintenance purposes. Additionally, rainfall patterns can affect transportation routes.

column3: Air transport
column9: ND
column10: Soil and sediment retention provides a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for infrastructure such as roads and airfields used during freight air transport activities.
column11: ND
column13: Freight air transport depends on the ecosystems and the atmosphere to dilute the pollutants emitted by aircraft.
column14: Frieght air transport depends on biological control provided by ecosystems to prevent infestations by pests, avoid damage to goods and and avoid damage to goods.
column15: Freight air transport depends on air filtration by the ecosystems to filter pollutants emitted by aircraft.
column16: Freight air transport is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect from flooding infrastructure such as roads and airfields.
column18: Freight air transport depends on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, and to reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage infrastructure or impact the efficiency of transportation operations.
column19: Freight air transport depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient quantity and quality of water, which is essential for aircraft function and is also needed for cleaning and maintenance.
column21: Vegetation forms a natural noise reduction structure to mediate noise impacts from air transportation.
column23: Freight air transport depend on regulation of micro and meso climate by ecosystems to ensure appropriate flight conditions (e.g. temperature, humidity, and wind fields).
column25: Freight air transport is dependent on storm mitigation ecosystem services to enable operation of air transport and protect infrastructure from the impacts of wind, sand and other storms.
column26: Freight air transport depends on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the buildings and infrastructure. The regulation of water flows helps ensure sufficient water supply even during dry periods, which is needed for cleaning and maintenance of aircraft and infrastructure.
column27: Freight air transport depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure maintenance of stable weather conditions.

column3: Water transport
column9: ND
column10: Soil and sediment retention mitigate landslides and freshwater coastal erosion, protecting infrastructure and enabling operation of inland water transport.
column11: Inland water transport depends on water purification by ecosystems to improve the quality of water in inland waterways and reduce the damage to boat materials from chemicals in the water.
column13: Inland water transport depends on the ecosystems and the atmosphere to dilute the pollutants emitted by gas or diesel powered ship engines.
column14: Inland water transport depends on biological control provided by ecosystems to prevent infestations by pests, avoid damage to goods and and avoid damage to goods.
column15: Inland water transport depends on air filtration by the ecosystems to filter pollutants emitted by gas or diesel powered ship engines.
column16: Inland water transport is dependent on flood mitigation services to protect infrastructure from flooding and to enable transport operations.
column18: Inland water transport depends on global climate regulation by ecosystems to mitigate climate change, and reduce the frequency and intensity of major climate events that could damage infrastructure and impact the efficiency of transportation operations.
column19: Inland water transport depends on water supply services provided by ecosystems to ensure sufficient water levels for transport operations. Certain level of quantity and quality of water is also needed for cleaning and maintenance of ships and related infrastructure.
column21: N/A
column23: Ecosystems regulate the micro climate in the locations of ports and other facilities used for water transport, enabling their operation (e.g. stabilising local temperature, humidity and regulating winds).
column25: Ecosystems mitigate the impacts of wind, sand and other storms (e.g. vegetation creating a barrier), which provides better conditions for inland water transport and protects the vessels and other infrastructure in and near waterways.
column26: Inland water transport is dependent on the water flow regulation services provided by ecosystems. Ecosystems mitigate the peak water flows that could lead to floods and damage the infrastructure on shore. The regulation of water flows helps ensure sufficient water supply even during dry periods, which ensures sufficient water levels to enable operation of water transport activities. Water supply is also needed for cleaning and maintenance.
column27: Inland water transportation depends on rainfall pattern regulation by ecosystems to ensure sufficient water levels for water transport operations. Water is also needed for cleaning and maintenance purposes.
column28: Some inland water transport activities depend on the recreational services provided by freshwater ecosystems. For example, some water transport activities depend on the availability of enjoyment or recreational opportunities (e.g. recreational fishing, recreational diving).
column29: Certain types of inland water transport depend on visual amenity services provided by ecosystems for attracting and creating a pleasurable experience for passengers (e.g. beautiful views attracting river cruise passangers).

column3: Accommodation
column4: Camping grounds, recreational vehicle parks and trailer parks
column8: Ecosystems provide biomass such as wood, which is used for camping grounds and other protective shelters.
column9: Many camping grounds, recreational vehicle parks and trailer parks deposit food and human waste in the surrounding areas. They depend on solid waste remediation services provided by ecosystems to transform organic substances.
column10: Camping grounds and facilities are dependent on soil and sediment retention to provide a stable substrate, erosion control, and landslide mitigation for buildings and infrastructure.
column11: Many camping grounds, recreational vehicle parks and trailer parks use water extracted from the ground or water body for activities such as cleaning or maintenance.
